name: None - No specific camera angle applied.
dutch angle - Creates a tilted horizon for a dynamic, unsettling effect.
fisheye - Produces a wide panoramic or hemispherical image, useful for extreme wide-angle shots.
from above - Captures the scene from a high vantage point.
from behind - Shows the subject from behind.
from below - Captures the subject from a low angle.
panorama - Produces a wide-angle view.
from below upskirt - A controversial and typically inappropriate angle capturing from below.
perspective - Emphasizes depth and spatial relationships.
pov - Point of view, shows what the subject sees.
sideways - Captures the scene from a side angle.
upside-down - Inverts the scene for a dramatic effect.
vanishing point - Emphasizes lines converging at a single point.
Overhead Shot - Captures the scene from directly above.
Dutch Angle - Creates a tilted horizon for a dynamic, unsettling effect.
Tracking Shot - Follows the subject as it moves.
Crane Shot - Captures the scene from a high, sweeping angle using a crane.
Handheld Shot - Uses a handheld camera for a shaky, realistic effect.
Tilt Shot - Tilts the camera up or down.
Pan Shot - Moves the camera horizontally.
Static Shot - Keeps the camera fixed in one position.
Close-Up Shot - Captures the subject tightly, often showing detail.
Wide Shot - Captures a wide view of the scene.
Establishing Shot - Sets the scene, often a wide shot.
Aerial Shot - Captures the scene from the air.
Point of View Shot - Shows what the subject sees.
Reverse Shot - Captures the scene from the opposite direction.
Low Angle Shot - Captures the subject from a low angle.
High Angle Shot - Captures the subject from a high angle.
Cutaway Shot - Cuts to a different scene or detail.
Reaction Shot - Shows the reaction of a character.
Two Shot - Captures two subjects in the frame.
Long Shot - Captures the subject from a distance.
Medium Shot - Captures the subject from a medium distance.
Whip Pan - Quickly moves the camera horizontally, blurring the image.
Dolly Shot - Moves the camera towards or away from the subject.
Zoom Shot - Changes the focal length to zoom in or out.
Insert Shot - Captures a detail of the scene.
Bird's-Eye View - Captures the scene from directly above.
